Final scoring takes place and the player with the most Victory Points wins.

name: Cards vs Dice: Strategically Evil
description:
Two of the world's oldest game elements finally come together in simple and perfect chaos. From the makers of CARDS vs. DICE -CLASSIC- Strategically Lucky comes CARDS vs. DICE -DIABLO- Strategically Evil. A family card game for kids and adults.

CARDS vs. DICE - CLASSIC is all about collecting "LUCKY" cards. However, -DIABLO- works with "EVIL" cards which, by collecting, can lead to elimination.

The deck of cards is dealt evenly among all players. During each turn, players roll two dice, one red and one white. Players then try to match the dice with the cards in their hand. Depending on the exact dice roll and the cards played, players will either gain, give, or avoid an "EVIL" card. If a player acquires seven (7) "EVIL" cards, they are eliminated.

Win the game by ridding yourself of all the cards in your hand or by eliminating the other player(s) by giving them "EVIL" cards. Each game typically lasts 5 to 10 minutes. Prepare yourself to get strategically evil.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Player Elimination

name: Star Wars: Jedi Master Trivia Board Game
description:
A Board Game for 2-6 Players.

The Game involves answering trivia questions about the six Star Wars Episodes. There are 700 questions and over 2,000 possible answers.

Who will become the Jedi Master?

The Board is divided into six sections, representing the six episodes. In order to progress the game, a player must answer questions correctly relating to the Episode/Zone that they are in. The Object of the game is to test your knowledge and be the first Jedi Knight to race through every Episode of the Star wars Saga to become the Jedi Master.

name: Golddiggers
description:
Bag yourself a rich guy (or a loser) in this free PNP push-your-luck dating game for 2 to 6 players.

In Golddiggers, you play the role of a Digger; an unlady-like lady who wants to bag herself a rich guy; a Gold guy. In order to get your Gold, you have to try and impress them at a number of social events hosted by yourself and your competitors. Fail to impress the Golds, and your only option will be a big, fat Loser!

You play the character of one of the women. Each round one of the players turns open a new event card and each of the players picks one of their talents to try and impress the Gold guys with. Then each player rolls a dice so see how succesfull they are.

Whoever gets the richest guys wins, but the more wealthy a Gold is, the harder it is to get them, and the more risk you run of ending up with the loser, so choose well!

name: Bushido: Waku
description:
The demon of legend Waku the collector of souls has returned. His power is only matched by his cruelty. His life force sustained by draining and claiming the lives of the living who appear on Jikoku’s list, an evil artefact that is said to be the source of his power suggesting that Waku is merely the avatar of an even greater threat. Conjecture aside this Yokai shugenja is without question a powerful weapon in Yurei’s arsenal. Broken followers of Yurei throw themselves in the path of kill strokes aimed at Waku in mindless devotion to their dark master. With a point of a twisted finger and the muttering of a few ancient pernicious words Waku’s enemies burst into a flames, wreathed in eerie green flame as they crumple and die in agony. Waku simply vanishes in a dense fog searching for the next victim to complete their death sentence.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and two full colour profile cards.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Yugio
description:
Yugio, once a pious and faithful peasant serving the burial grounds of his hamlet. However this once loyal and honest man, like so many, has been corrupted. The long days spent on his own listening to ancestors began to turn his beliefs, vile and impure. Little did Yugio realise that voices he believed were his ancestors were those of Yurei. Now a broken and maddened shadow of his former self, another puppet, bent to the will of a dark and ruthless master, his former teachings twisted to benefit the Shugenja of the Cult. The Shoymo taught to him to protect the spirits and souls of his ancestors now turned against their peoples.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and one full colour profile card.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Mokoti, Komuso Monk
description:
The Komuso monks are usually a happy sight for the villagers and peasants, when these nomadic musicians come to town it is an opportunity to down tools and sit and listen to the sweet music played in exchange for a meal and a warm bed. Mokoti has fallen to the seductive charms of Yurei and whilst his playing is exquisite his motivations are far darker. The gentle and light music hides a twisted a corrupt whisper from the dark, bending the minds of the weak and vulnerable to His will.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and one full colour profile card.

name: Pizza Diavolo
description:
Putting the right toppings on pizza is not easy if each guest has his own special preferences.
Play up to four of the transparent cards in order to carry out the current order.

The pizza maker tries to assemble the desired combination of slices by using the right transparent cards and serve them while they are hot.

name: Muchik Pocket Edition
description:
This is the pocket edition of Muchik Spondylus Princeps, using only cards.
To win the game, a player must be the one controlling the Mochica card allowing its owner to win the game. In order to be in control of that card, players will battle with other cards (pallares & fierras cards).
Mochica cards are trump cards that give a specific power to the player who owns one. One of the cards allow to win the game, another to draw more cards, etc.
When a player attacks another, he can play Fierras or Pallares cards. Fierras are played first. The target player discards as many cards as the attacking player's Fierras cards values.
Pallares are played little by little : the attacking player plays some, the defender can counter by equalling the value, the attacking adds more, etc. If the attacker wins, he/she picks one card in the target player's hand at random for himself.
It is possible to pass a turn to draw more cards.

name: Veja o mundo
description: Brazil's weekly magazine "Veja" contains news of Brazil and the world. Veja o Brasil ("See Brazil") is a trivia game compiled from facts found in the magazine. Move your pieces around the board and answer questions from six categories. Contains 1800 questions on 300 cards. Game is in Portuguese.

name: Sushi Dice: Barbecue
description:
Description from the publisher:

Sushi Dice: Barbecue is a mini-expansion for Sushi Dice available at Spiel 2016. During set-up, randomly replace two cards from the box with the Barbecue cards. These new cards are used during the game the same way as any other card; the only difference is that the combinations are a little bit more complicated. One of these cards requires a "Yuck".
categories: Action / Dexterity, Dice, Party Game, Real-time
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: - KUFU - (クフ)
description:
User summary
ー　ＫＵＦＵ　ー (クフ) is a Japanese co-op game, where the players explore a Pharaoh's pyramid in the manner of I. Jones. The game was released (and sold out) at the Tokyo Game Market in May 2017 in a very small, home-made production run.

The explorers must discover three chambers within the pyramid; the King's chamber, the Queen's chamber, and the King's hidden chamber, and then find the exit and escape. To do so, they have an ancient document and must decipher its instructions to reveal the pyramid's secrets. Failure means the curse of the Pharaoh will strike!

They fail if they run out of time, or if they cannot explore any more, having misread the secret writings. Key to the game is the ancient book which the players hold. At the start of the game, the pages in the book are mixed up. The players can only read a few pages from the start, and then place a bookmark on a page. The pages have actions, traps, and some icons to discover.

If the bookmarked page is an action, it is activated. If it is a trap, it is disabled. But traps that are not bookmarked can be triggered. Some pages grant icons to be carried be a player, and some actions need icons to activate. Since this is a co-operative expedition, players may swap icons between them, but at the cost of a player's turn.

The players have a limited set of bookmarks, and so must choose carefully which pages to mark. They can continue deciphering the book from a previous bookmark, but only a few pages at a time.

When the start player's turn comes around, the time token moves, which might invoke the curse! If so, the players must escape the pyramid quickly or perish!

The pyramid is made from wood and plastic, the rooms from folded paper, and the ancient book is a filofax - a refillable pocket binder. The bookmarks are small post-it notes. The game is long and weighs a kilo.

Players comments on Twitter say the game reminds them a little of T.I.M.E Stories, a game bound by time. And that the home-made appearance is deceiving, the gameplay is very strong. The actual pages from the ancient book are not shown anywhere, maintaining the secrecy of the game (which therefore must be very language dependent).

Publisher's summary
Excavate the newly found pyramid. Decipher the ancient document, deactivate the deadly traps and find your way to exit safely.

新しく見つかったピラミッドを探索せよ。　手元の古文書を解読し、危険な罠を解除しながら無事地上へ脱出するのだ。
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Turn Order: Time Track
publishers: るりるりゲームズ (ruri ruri games)

name: Perry Konai de
description:
User summary:
ペリーは来ないで (Perry Konai de) is a card game by the doujin circle 哀愁旅館きたぐに (Aisyu Ryokan Kitaguni) released for the Game Market Tokyo 2017 Spring board game convention in Japan, Tokyo, Odaiba in May 2017.

The game's name translate roughly as 'Don't come Perry'.

The character of Perry refers to Matthew C. Perry, the Commodore of the United States Navy who played a Major role in opening to Japan in 19th century.

In this game each player is trying to collect poos to prevent Perry, attracted by their gold, from coming to their port.
The players take turns in drawing cards and playing them any face they want up in from of themselves or any other player.
If a card is played in a manner that it pincers other cards, a la Othello, the cards in between get flipped: a Poo card become a Gold card, and a Gold card become a Poo card.
At the end of a round, the player with the most Gold cards must draw a Point card. When a player exceeds the maximum number of points, the game stops and the player with the less points wins.

The manual is in Japanese but you don't really need Japanese to play the game.

Description from the back of the box:
ペリーの熱い視線がいまジパングに注がれている。
「ペリー来ないで」はオセロのギミックを取り入れた競争型カードゲームです。
プレイヤーは自分の港に黄金を貯めつつペリーがこちらに来ないようウ〇コも溜めましょう。
publishers: 哀愁旅館きたぐに (Aisyu Ryokan Kitaguni)

name: Dungeoning
description:
User summary:
ダンジョニング (Dungeoning in Japanese) is a RPG Adventure-like card game by the Japanese doujin circle T-Club released for the 'Game Market 2016 Autumn' convention in Nagoya, Japan in 2016.

Dungeoning is a video-game RPG-themed co-operative exploration game. One player plays the Dark Lord and the remaining players each one hero.

The Dark Lord powers have been sealed off and he's weak. However, he is recovering slowly in his Dungeon.

Aware of the coming crisis, the brave heroes enter the Dungeon and start their quest to defeat the Dark Lord in his Dungeon before he can recover his powers.
If they manage to do so they win. Otherwise the Dark Lord kills them and reign over the world.

The Heroes' goal is to reach the Dark Lord to defeat him for good. From the entrance, they need to reach the Dark Lord's throne: if any Hero player can move to the same room as him, the Heroes wins.
The Dark Lord's goal is to recover enough power or kill off all the Hero players.

The Game plays roughly as the following.

0) Setup
First one player gets choosen to be the Dark Lord for the game. He picks up the black character.
Shuffle all the Hazard cards together, return 3 cards to the box and deal 3 to the Dark Lord.
Then, each hero player chooses a colored character and gets assigned randomly a Job card.
Last but not least, the Dungeon tile cards are shuffled layed out as a grid, face down, except for the Dark Lord's throne, in the top left corner, and the dungeon's entrace, in the bottom right corner. Place the Dark Lord character on his throne and the Hero characters all at the entrance.

1) Heroes' Turn
Each heroes choose secretly one of the following action: Move, Heal or Ability.
When all decided, all the Heroes reveal their action at once and proceed to resolution. The play order doesn't matter here.
Each dungeon tile card represents two rooms. Heroes can only enter a room if there is no wall blocking access. Players will reveal dungeon tile cards as needed when exploring new areas of the dungeon. Be careful of traps!

2) Dark Lord's Turn
During he can play choose on of the following action: accumulate power, play an Hazard card to attack/delay the Heroes, or renew his hand.

Repeat 1) and 2) until either:
- any hero reaches the same room as the Dark Love -> the Heroes win
- the Dark Lord has killed all the Heroes or has exhausted the Hazard cards deck.

Description from the publisher:
『ダンジョニング』は協力型ダンジョン探索ゲームです。
プレイヤーは勇者（２～４人）と魔王（１人）に分かれて戦います。
魔王は完全復活するまで、勇者が近づけないよう邪魔をしてください。
勇者は完全復活する前に魔王に近づき封印してください。
勇者達の意思疎通が勝利の鍵です！
categories: Card Game, Exploration, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Role Playing, Team-Based Game

name: Invisible Think
description: In Invisible Think, players take turns racing against time to get their teammates to guess the word on the drawing card. However, in this game of "invisible ink" there is a twist - players or the entire team will also wear special red lens glasses that make the red-ink drawing invisible to the eye!

name: The Spanish Civil War
description:
The Spanish Civil War is an Axis & Allies variant that takes place in Spain from 1936 - 1939.

It is in the form of a booklet and comes with:
Two 11" by 17" game maps
One 12 page rule book
One sheet of cut out counters

In addition to this game, you will need a set of plastic military figures to represent the game units and at least on ten sided die.

name: Deck Around
description:
You pick a random slang term from the deck and everyone writes a made up but convincing definition for the word and anonymously hands it in.

One person reads all the definitions aloud, including the actual definition of the word, which is randomly mixed in.

Everyone guesses which definition is the real one and get points if they do. They usually fall for someone else's bullshit definition -- which earns its author a point.

Differences to regular balderdash would be more of a party-game for the adult crowd, adult-material.

name: Butlerian Jihad
description:
A two player card game themed on The Butlerian Jihad in the Dune Universe as described by the Prequel Trilogy. After a thousand-year standoff, the War between the Free Human League of Nobles Worlds and the Intelligent Machine controlled Synchronized Worlds escalates.

One player is the Humans. The other player is the Machines. Each player has their own unique deck. Each deck has 6 suits. Each card has a force value and a special ability. Some special abilities require their ability to be activated, other abilities automatically take effect when the card is recruited or as a Free action discarded from the hand or in-play.

Each player starts the game with 3 Empire Tokens.

Each round has 6 Phases.

1. Initiative Phase
- Players roll high on 1D6. High roll is the attacker. Low roll is the defender.

2. Fate Phase
- Each player draws 5 cards from the top of his deck.

3. Strategy Phase
- Each player may discard up to 2 cards and draw replacements.

4. Battle Phase
- Players take turns starting with the attacker. On his turn a player can either Recruit (put a card into play face up in front them), Activate (use the activation ability of a card in play if it has one) or Pass.
- If both players Pass, one after the other, the Phase ends.
- Once a player passes, he must continue to pass, unless his opponent causes one of his in-play cards to be discarded or eliminated.
- Normally, during the round, a player can only recruit a max of one card from each of the six suits. Some cards as their special ability allow you to recruit more than 1 card of a particular suit.
- A card can only be activated once per round.

5. Resolution Phase
- Add up the modified force values of all the cards in-play. The player with the highest score wins. If tied, players roll high on 1D6 to determine winner.
- The winner takes an Empire Token from the loser.
- The winner causes one target in-play card of his opponent to be discarded.

6. End Phase
- Each player can allow up to 9 of their in-play cards to remain in play. Excess cards must be discarded.
- Max hand size is 3 cards. Discard excess cards

The first player to control all 6 Empire Tokens wins the game.

name: Samurai Warfare
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players.

Players share a common deck comprising six card types: Shogun, Terrain, Samurai, Ashigaru, Strategy, Special. Cards have a force value between 1 and 10 and may also have an associated battle action

Each turn has 7 Phases:

1. Preparations Phase
- Each player fills their hand to 8 cards.

2. Strategy Phase
- Each player may discard up to 3 cards and draw replacements.

3. Tactics Phase
- Starting with the Shogun and going clockwise, each player may in turn play (discard) 1 card. The type of card discarded will determine what effect is produced:

4. Battle Phase
- Players take turns playing 1 card each face up to the table in front of their owner. Some cards have battle actions as described in the card list (player extra card, destroy target card etc.). When played in this phase, the battle action immediately takes effect. This continues until all players have played all cards they possibly can. A player may have a max of 1 of each card type in play.

5. Victory Phase
- Each player adds up the force values of all his cards in play. The highest score wins and gains a Victory Token. All played cards are discarded.

6. Shogun Phase
- The winner of the turn becomes the Shogun.

7. End Phase
- Players may discard up to 1 card from their hand if they have any cards in their hand.

The first player to amass 5 Victory Tokens (VT) wins the game.

name: Siege of Sleeping Mountain
description:
Siege of Sleeping Mountain (May 1999) is a Learn to Play set for The Legend of the Five Rings. It contains two sets of two decks:

Toturi's Army vs Naga
Brotherhood vs Dragon Clan
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: Storms Over Matsu Palace
description: Storms Over Matsu Palace was the third Learn to Play set of Legend of the Five Rings Card Collectible Game and developed the Battle of the Valley of Storms, in which the Unicorn approached Matsu Palace to investigate the use of maho, being decimated by the Lion defenders and their oni allies. This set featured starter decks for the Unicorn and Lion Clan.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: HOUTEN 1905 (奉天1905)
description:
User summary
奉天1905 (HOUTEN 1905), the decisive Battle of Mukden during the Russo-Japanese war sets the stage for this head-to-head war card game. Players lead either the Japanese or Russian military in an attempt to fulfill one of a number of requirements for victory.

Choose three out of six command cards to manipulate your military troops. March forward to outnumber your enemy’s troops or max out your enemy’s damage tokens to win the battle. Plan your card combinations and predict your opponent’s timing for this brief battle of minds.

Publisher's summary
日露戦争奉天会戦の対戦ウォーカードゲームです。
プレーヤーは日本軍あるいはロシア軍を担当して
複数の勝利条件のうち1つの達成を目指して戦います。

ゲームは6つの命令カードのうち3つを選択して
各々の軍隊を操作します。
進軍し相手を押し切るか、相手に被害トークン全てを受け取らせば
勝利となります。
カードの組み合わせやタイミングを読み合う短時間の心理戦になっています。

name: Swordpoint: Classical Armies
description:
Army list book containing 59 armies with additional variants, covering the period from 700 BC to 300 AD. Army lists include:

Scythian - 700 BC
Etruscan - 700 BC
Later Lydian - 615 BC
Early Rome - 600 BC
Early Hoplite Greece - 600 BC
Persians and Medes - 550 BC
Thracian - 500 BC
Hispania - 500 BC
Southern Italian - 500 BC
Republican Indian - 500 BC
Ligurian - 500 BC
Italian Hill Tribes - 500 BC
Illyrian - 500 BC
Gallic - 500 BC
Early Carthaginian - 500 BC
Classical Indian - 500 BC
Campanian - 500
Later Achaemenid Persia - 420 BC
Warring States Chinese - 403 BC
Syracusan - 400 BC
Later Hoplite Greece - 400 BC
Early Republican Rome - 400 BC
Macedon - 359 BC
Macedonian Successor - 323 BC
Lysimachid Successor - 323 BC
Eumenid Successor - 323 BC
Antigonid Successor - 323 BC
Twilight of Greece - 300 BC
Seleucid - 300 BC
Sarmatian - 300 BC
Pyrrhic - 300 BC
Ptolemaic Egyptian - 300 BC
Pergamene - 281 BC
Galatian - 280 BC
Later Carthaginian - 270 BC
Later Macedon - 260 BC
Parthian - 250 BC
Numidian - 250 BC
Bactrian Greek - 250 BC
Polybian Republican Rome - 210 BC
Han Chinese - 206 BC
Xiongnu - 200 BC
Northern British - 200 BC
Bastarnae - 200 BC
Armenia - 190 BC
Maccabean Revolt and Hasmonean Kingdom of Judea - 168 BC
Early German - 150 BC
Slave Revolt - 150 BC
Kushan - 140 BC
Pontic - 110 BC
Later Republican Rome - 105 BC
British Tribes - 100 BC
Dacian - 82 BC
Early Imperial Rome - 30 BC
Early Sudanese - 30 BC
Alans - 50 AD
Middle Imperial Rome - 193 AD
Sassanid Persian - 220 AD
Palmyran - 260 AD
categories: Ancient, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Manifest Destiny
description:
A card game based on the western expansion of North America during the period between the War of 1812 and the American Civil War.

Players share a common deck comprising 8 suits of between 15 and 23 cards: Warfare, Government, Population, Transport, Economics, Motivation, Land, Discouragement. To start each player is dealt 7 cards.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 phases:


Draw Phase
Draw 3 cards from the Deck and put them in your hand.

Action Phase
Discard 1 card to gain the benefit according to its type:
Warfare (Gain 2 Victory Points).
Government (Steal 1 Random card from an opponent’s hand).
Population (Draw 3 cards then discard any 2 cards from your hand).
Transport (Look at next 5 cards in deck and put 1 in your hand).
Economics (Look at an opponent’s hand. Take 1 card and give him 1 card).
Motivation (Draw 2 cards).
Land (Draw 1 card and gain 1 Victory Point).
Discouragement (Opponent must discard 1 random card from his hand).


Meld Phase
You may make 1 or more melds or super melds this turn.
A meld has 3 or more cards of a single type: a meld of 3 cards earns 5 Victory Points (VP), a meld of 4 cards earns 10 VP, a meld of 5 cards earns 15 VP and so on.
A Super meld has 5 or more cards of all different types: a super meld of 5 cards earns 15 VP, a super meld of 6 cards earns 20 VP, a super meld of 7 cards earns 25 VP.
Every time you make a meld draw 2 replacement cards.
Immediately discard all melded cards.
Discouragement cards cannot be used in any type of meld.

End Phase
Max hand size is 10 cards. Discard excess cards.



The game ends after each player has had 10 turns. The player with the most Victory Points wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Gespensterburg
description:
Players play ghosts trying to get out of the castle. They spin a wheel (which simulates a die roll) to move their ghosts. When the land on a yellow field, the cassette is played and gives instructions on what to do. This can be things like moving towards a certain room, skipping a turn or taking an extra turn. The first ghost to get out of the castle wins the game.

The instructions consists just of two sentences on how to contruct the wheel and five sentences of actual game instructions.

name: Rifle and Axe
description:
A worker placement game for 1-4 players themed on the Pioneer Settlement of Kentucky in 1780. Settlements simulate places such as Harrods Fort, Logans Fort, and Boones Station with each player representing the settlement leader.

Each player has a Resource Board, a Structure Board and a set of cubes/tokens to track resources and activities.
- The resource board is a 5x5 grid of 25 spaces and is used to keep track of the 25 different type of players’ resources (Folk, Housing, Clothing, Happiness etc.) Each resource has a specific starting value between 0 and 10 and will go up and down during the game as a consequence of decisions made and a range of random factors. Resources are used to expand and develop the players’ settlement and their use will need to be balanced to ensure a positive outcome.
- The Structure Board is a 4x4 grid of 16 spaces and used to keep track of a player’s structures. Each player starts with 10 cabins and 2 corral pens but additional structures can be built to expand the settlement. Structures will require varying combinations of resources (labour, wood and lumber) to construct but will generate benefits for the settlement once built.

Players share an Action Board. The Action Board is used in the action phase and consists of a 6 x 5 grid of 30 spaces representing the 30 actions that can be taken by players. Actions (e,g, clear land, hunting, soap making etc.) represent the activities undertaken by the settlers. Most actions have limits such as resource availability or need for specialists but, if requirements are met, will lead to additional resources and/or advancement of the settlement.

Players can take their turns simultaneously with each turn comprising 2 phases:

1. Growth Phase
- Roll once on the Growth Table per 20 Folk you have. Results will result in births or the arrival of immigrants (with some additional resources)

2. Livestock Phase
- Gain additional livestock per 5 livestock you own.

3. Boon Phase
- Roll 1D10 to gain benefits, normally in additional resources.

4. Action Phase
- Players get actions equal to their Folk resource score. Cubes are placed onto the action squares of the Action Board to reflect actions taken. Adjust resource levels up and down accordingly. At the end of the phase all cubes are removed from the Action Board.

5. Hardship Phase
- Roll 1D10 on the Hardship Table and resolve. Hardship will result in loss of livestock, grain, food or folk.

6. Mishap Phase
- Roll 1D10 twice on the Mishap Table and resolve. Mishaps result in the loss of resources.

7. Raid Phase
- Roll 1D10 on the Indian Raid Table and resolve. Results will be trade, fighting, theft of resources, and in certain cases the settlement might be overrun and the player eliminated from the game.

8. Consume Phase
- Each of a player’s folk consumes 1 Food and every 10 folk consume 1 salt. Insufficient food or salt may lead to folk moving away or dying.

9. Seasonal Phase
- Each turn represents three months - keep track of the seasons - Spring to Summer to Fall to Winter. If it is Winter roll once on the Winter Table and resolve. Dependant on the severity of the winter additional fuel (wood and lumber) may be required and there may be a loss of livestock or folk.

10. Storage Phase
- A player adds up the total number of Grain, Food, Lye, Salt, and Gunpowder units he has. If this number is more than the number of containers held he must lose the difference.

11. Happiness Phase
- Gain 2D6 Happiness. Gain or lose happiness dependant on conditions within the settlement.

12. End Phase
- Ensure all counters and tokens are correctly placed, and no phases or players were skipped.

The game lasts 5 years (20 turns). The Player with the most awards at the end of the game wins. There are 5 awards:
- Population Award: Most Folk
- Happiness Award: Most Happiness
- Builder Award: Most Structures + Plots
- Prosperity Award: Most Money
- Hoarder Award: Most Grain + Livestock + Food

name: Last Men Standing
description:
A solo card game in tribute to the genre of Squad Level, Suicide Mission, Ensemble Cast, Survival, War Movies such as: Sahara, Saving Private Ryan, The Big Red One, The Dirty Dozen, The Desert Rats etc.

There are 4 Decks:
- Soldier Deck - these are the soldiers you start with and some you acquire along the way. Most soldiers provide 1 to 3 skills (from a total of 18).
- Aid Deck - these are help and friends you acquire during the game. Most aid cards provide 1 to 2 skills.
- Mission Deck - this is the one main objective you are trying to achieve in the last game turn. Most missions require 4 specific skills to complete.
- Encounter Deck - these are the foes and difficulties you encounter along the way. Most encounters require 1 to 3 specific skills to overcome them.

To start:
- Draw 12 soldiers. You may discard up to 4 soldiers and draw replacements. Soldier cards are kept face up in front of you.
- Draw 4 aid cards and put them in your hand.
- Draw 1 mission card and place it face up.
- Draw 14 encounter cards. Place these face down in a row leading up to the mission card. This is called the encounter row.

Each turn has 3 Phases:

1. Aid Phase
- Draw 1 aid card and put it in your hand.

2. Encounter Phase
- Flip over the next card in the encounter row and see what skills it requires to be overcome.
- Check your soldiers and aid cards to see if you have those skills. If you are missing one or more skills, a random soldier is killed.
- If you needed to use one or more aid cards discard them.
- If you completed the encounter successfully roll 1D6: on a roll of 5 or 6 a random soldier is killed anyway (these are dangerous missions).
- If all the encounters are finished, the squad faces the final mission. When facing the final mission you may draw an extra 2 aid cards.
- You only win the game if the final Mission is completed successfully.

3. End Phase
- Max hand size is 5 aid cards. Discard excess cards.

Play a maximum of 30 turns. To win complete the last mission, and have at least 1 soldier survive.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, World War II

name: Chiyawa
description:
Chiyawa is a casual game where players who assume to be Farmers seek to feed their animals. The game is played by rolling a dice and then moving to feed your own animal with the grass thus the origin of the name CHIYAWA (which means GRASS in Hausa Language).

Player: 2-4 players

Time: 15 minutes average

Content:

I Game board
40 Playing Token
1 dice

How to Play

1. Players set their animal pen (each player has 10 animals which is signified by the same colour)
2. Players start the game by rolling the dice (any player can start the game)
3. Rolling 6 or 3 on the dice allows you bring your animal o the GATE. When players roll a 6, they play again. The difference between 6 and 3 is that, rolling a 6 allows you to roll the dice again while 3 doesn’t.
4. Once animals are brought to the gate, any number rolled can move them on the board either vertically, horizontally or diagonally. They can also move forward and backwards. However, animals will move towards one direction at each turn. For instance, if a player rolls a 4, if they choose to move vertically, they cannot change direction until their next run.
5. Players can bring in as much animals to the gate as they want till there is no animal to bring as long as they are getting 6 and 3 or they can decided to move the animal already at the gate.

Moving on the board

1. Players can move forward or backward
2. Players can move vertically, diagonally, horizontally but can’t combine them at once in a turn. If player starts moving vertically, they have to finish it.

Eating Grass

Once any animal is eating grass (when an animal is on a grass box), it is considered that the space/grass is gone in the game and so will not be counted anymore. This means that when any player is moving their animal, they MUST JUMP the space that has another animal on it to the next available space in that direction.

Water

The water on the board is a bonus attraction. Once on it, it simply means to move one step immediately to any direction.

Balance of SIX (6)

If all your animals are in play (that means there are no more animal in your pen) or at the gate and you roll a 6, it means you would have to withdraw an animal that is not already eating grass back to the pen.

End of game

The game ends when any players finish feeding their animals.

To Win

The first farmer (player) to get all their animals to feed (eat grass) wins the game.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition

name: Guardians of the Galaxy
description:
A card game based on Galaxy of the Guardians Movie and Comics.

There are 2 Decks:
- The Guardian Deck. Each Guardian card will have one or more Traits: Hero, Ship, Gear, Tactics, Star Lord, Pirate, Nova Corps, etc. Guardian cards generate force points which are needed to capture Adventure cards. Guardian cards have a base force between 1 and 5. In combination some Guardian cards will generate additional Force.
- The Adventure Deck. The 12 Adventures have a force between 17 and 25 requiring multiple Guardian cards to be melded to complete them.

To start flip over the top card of the Adventure deck and deal 5 Guardian cards to each player.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 5 phases:

1. Peril Phase
- If an Adventure was completed last turn, flip over the top card of the Adventure deck. Normally there will only be 1 face up adventure card at a time.

2. Hero Phase
- If your hand is less than 7 cards fill it to 7. Otherwise draw 2 cards.

3. Action Phase
- You may discard a Tactics card to draw 2 cards (max once this phase).
- You may discard a Pirate card to look at one of your opponents’ hands and steal 1 card.
- You may discard a Place card to discard your hand and draw 7 new cards.
- You may discard a Ship card to look at next Adventure card.

4. Adventure Phase
- You may play cards to make a meld.
- The combined force of all cards in the meld must equal or exceed the force of the current Adventure in which case you complete it and put it in your Victory Pile. Then discard all cards in the meld. When making a meld, you can only use one card representing an individual Hero, or Ship, or Thing.

5. End Phase
- Max hand size is 8 cards. Discard excess cards. You may also discard additional unwanted cards as well.

The game ends when all Adventure cards have been completed. The player with the most force points worth of Adventure cards in your Victory Pile at the end of the game is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: BattleCON: Khadath Ahemusei – Planar Paragon Costume
description: An new Unique Ability card with alternate art for Khadath Ahemusei from BattleCON: War of Indines.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Payroll
description:
Description from the designer:

Payroll is a worker placement, resource management game that will test your ability to build a successful business. Compete with up to four players to win the public's approval and have the best reputation in the industry.

Build your company, hire employees, and delegate how they spend their time. Utilize their specific skills and find out who they work best with. Make your company more profitable as you continue to expand. Your choices will affect your company’s reputation and decide the outcome of the game!

Throughout the game you will be competing for actions on the main desk. You will have to balance how much time and money you invest to expand your business and increase your reputation. If you expand too quickly, you may not be able to pay your employees. If you focus too much on quick money, you may not reach your full potential. Finding the balance, knowing your competition, and a little luck will be the key to building your business empire!

name: Glorious Empires
description:
A dice and card game of civilization building for 2-4+ players.

Each player has a set of 8 six-sided dice and share 6 common decks of cards:
- The Leader, Wonder, Culture and Resources decks each have cards with a Victory Points (VP) value between 1 and 25, but may score additional VP in combination with other cards (from the same or different decks) or have other special abilities.
- Disaster Deck. These cards have a VP value between -1 and -25 and have negative effects such as losing leaders or wonders, starvation or being attacked by barbarians. Players should do their best to avoid acquiring disasters.
- Conquest Deck. These cards have a VP value between 1 and 25 but no special abilities.

Each turn is divided into phases:
1. All players roll their dice simultaneously.
2. Players may re-roll some, all, or none of their dice.
3. Players may a second time re-roll some, all, or none of their dice.
4. The player who rolled the most ones gets the top Leader card.
5. The player who rolled the most twos gets the top Wonder card.
6. The player who rolled the most threes gets the top Conquest card.
7. The player who rolled the most fours gets the top Resource card.
8. The player who rolled the most fives gets the top Culture card.
9. The player who rolled the most sixes gets the top Disaster card.
If there is a tie in any category, the tied players roll one die each. Highest roll wins the tiebreaker.
Players put the cards they have won in front of themselves, visible to all.

The game ends after 20 turns. Each card has a Victory Point (VP) value. Each player adds up the points of all their cards to get a VP total. The player with the most VP at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Railway Rivals Map IR: Iran
description:
An expansion map for Railway Rivals and Dampfross. It has been sold at various conventions.

The map covers the country of Iran, with one hex representing approximately 46 kilometers.
mechanics: Crayon Rail System, Network and Route Building

name: Railway Rivals Map KT: Kentucky and Tennessee
description:
An expansion map for Railway Rivals and Dampfross. It has been sold at various conventions.

The map covers the States of Kentucky and Tennessee, with one hex representing approximately 17 kilometers.
mechanics: Crayon Rail System, Network and Route Building

name: The Athenians
description:
A card game for 2-4 players in which players are Athenian generals (Strategos) in the 5th century accumulating influence and prestige.

Players share a common set of cards of 8 different types: Proposal (gain prestige one time), Events (multiple effects), Associates (gain prestige every turn), Prosecutions (remove associates & strategoi), Popularity (temporary influence gain), Reaction (multiple effects), Victory (gain influence) and Defeat (lose influence)

Each player starts the game controlling one leader. There are 16 different leaders available and each has a unique special ability. If your leader is ever killed or removed from play, you must start over but keep any prestige already earned. Each player starts with 10 Influence and 10 Prestige.

Each round has 6 phases:

1. Enemy Phase
- Roll 1D6: if even Persia is the enemy; if odd Sparta is the enemy this round.

2. Availability Phase
- Flip over the top 5 + X cards of the deck where X is the number of players. These are placed face up in the middle of the table. These cards are known as the available cards.

3. Turn Order Phase
Players roll high 1D6 to determine turn order this round.

4. Action Phase
- Players take turns (in turn order) selecting one available card until all cards have been selected.
--- If a player selects a Popularity or Reaction card, they put that card in their hand. These are retained until needed to influence votes, or negate an event.
--- If a player selects an Associate, that associate becomes theirs and is placed face up in front of them.
--- If a player picks a Proposal or a Prosecution then a vote is conducted immediately to see which player wins it.
--- If a player picks an Event card resolve it immediately.
--- If a player selects a Victory or Defeat, it becomes theirs and is placed face up in front of them.

5. Prestige Phase
- Associates earn prestige for their leaders.

6. End Phase
- Max hand size is 4 cards discard excess cards.

The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck. At the end of the game, the player with the most prestige points wins.

name: Syrian Civil War
description:
A card game for 2-6 players based on the Syrian Civil War from 2011.

There are 6 factions, one of which is secretly assigned to each player, and an event deck of 37 card representing nations, organisations and activities which may have a positive or negative effect on one or more of the factions.

To start six faction cards (one for each faction) are placed face up in the middle of the table and 10 Victory Tokens (VT) placed on each card. Using a duplicate set of faction cards – one is secretly assigned to each player and remaining faction cards removed from play.

Players then take turns to draw 2 event cards from the top of the deck. One card is played and the other discarded. Played events will cause some factions to gain VT and others to lose VT. The played event is also discarded after its effects are taken. Cards are discarded face down.

The game ends when the event deck has been run through twice. The player with the faction with the highest number of VT at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Pitch, Please!
description:
The Game of the Sixty Second Screen play

With a deck of 53 illustrated movie cliches, Players will take turns pitching competing movies. A third player- the Producer, judges which pitch wins. That winner goes on to Produce the next round. And so forth, until the deck runs out or people need a nap. Whomever has the most winning pitch cards at the end of the night is the big winner. Or, whoever has the most fun.

One minute to plan it, and one minute to pitch it- Pitch, Please!

This game from cartoonist/humorist Carolyn Main is a improvisational party game, taking players to the movies- inside their own minds.

Pitch, Please! It's the big screen, in a lil' package.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Salisbury Plain
description:
Salisbury Plain is a light 4X game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game. Your tribe of celts are seeking to dominate Salisbury Plain by controlling a majority of its sacred sites. To do so, you must explore the land, harvest resources, grow your tribe, and wrest control of the standing stones from other tribes.

The game can be played by up to 5 players with the Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game, or up to 7 players if the Stonehenge: Nocturne Expansion is also used.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board, Worker Placement

name: Hey! Yo lo Vi Primero
description:
Challenge your mind, choose the images and find them as fast as you can. Have fun while you exercise your memory. The firs player who finds all the images wins!

The game offers 2 levels of difficulty, three variants.

name: Russia and the West
description:
A card game for 2 players in which one player represents the West, the other Russia. The premise of the game is that since the end of the Cold War and the fall of the Soviet Union as a Superpower, Russia has maintained an active war-footing with the West, using every means possible (covert, hacking, criminal, disinformation, hard force, etc.) to subvert and destabilise the Western powers and the new world order. The long term goal is to remain a major player in an illiberal, multi-polar world.

Players share a common deck. Some cards can be used by both players. Some cards can only be used by one side.

The game starts in the year 2000 with each turn representing 2 years. The game ends in 2020. There are a total of 11 turns which proceed as follows:

1. Players are dealt 7 cards each.

2. A player may reveal a spy card to look at his opponent’s hand.

3. Players can discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

4. A player may discard an economic card to draw 2 cards.

5. A player may discard a military card to make his opponent discard a random card

6. A player may discard a political card to draw 3 cards and discard 2 cards.

7. A player may discard a culture card to gain 1 Victory point.

8. Players reveal their hands.

9. The player with the highest force total wins the hand. Every card has a force value but a player can only count cards that match his side or that can be used by both players. A player may only use 1 card of the same type, so for example, he could use one military card toward his total but not two. This is the “One-Type-only Rule”. If a player reveals a crime card, however, he may break the One-Type-Only Rule, once, unless his opponent plays a law card.

10. Discard all cards.

If any player wins 3 hands in a row, they win the game. Otherwise the winner of the first turn gets 1 Victory point (VP), the winner of the second turn gets 2 VP, the winner of the third turn gets 3 VP and so on. The player with the most VP at the end of the game wins.

name: Pizza Service
description:
Pizza service is a famous place where the best and fastest pizzas in town are made. That's the way it was done from the beginning, but today... Guests have arrived, orders have been placed, but chef is anxious because he had taken new pizza makers in training, and they don't know where things are in this kitchen.

In this memory-style game from the 90's, pizza ingredients are spread face-down across the board. All players need the same ingredients to make their pizza and a die determines which one they should be looking for on their turn. The first player to get all the ingredients for the pizza wins the game.

name: Wagonimo
description:
With the Janod Matching Game, Wagonimo you must be the first to reconstruct your 5-carriage train with all of its animals by taking it in turns to roll the dice.

During each turn kids roll the action dice and add to his train a wagon or an animal: when the train is complete with 5 wagon and 5 animal on it the game ends. Players gain points with an animal on a wagon with the same color.

This very simple collecting game is perfect for children aged 3 years plus and will help your child to distinguish between animals and to match colours while developing fine motor skills.

name: Little White Lie
description:
What's wrong with a little white lie? Well it depends on how far it spreads, because you will eventually get caught.

Little White Lie is a tiny game by Christopher Chung (Lanterns) where 2 players try to spread a lie before too many people find out. Cards are held so that only your opponent can see them, and you will decide to pass or challenge, using some deduction to spell the word LIE. there are only 3 letters and 3 numbers in this nano game, yet it can get very tricky.

—description from the publisher

name: Blood, Bilge and Iron Balls: Naval Wargame Rules for the Age of Sail
description:
Blood, Bilge and Iron Balls is a set of wargame rules for naval battles in the Age of Sail.

With them you can recreate the triumphs of Nelson or Hawke or tackle pirates on the Spanish Main.

The rules themselves are very simple and easy to learn.

Each player can easily command a single ship or several, the rules working equally well for a single frigate chasing down a privateer, or a large-scale fleet action with multiple players on each side.

The basic rules have been written with the emphasis on providing a fast-playing and fun game, but optional rules are included which will add a greater level of historical realism and detail.

A unique card-driven turn sequence prevents the game becoming too predictable.

Also included are a selection of scenarios for re-fighting specific historical battles and simple campaign rules.

Although intended for use with model ships, the rule book includes sheets of ship counters which can be used to get started.

Just add dice, tape measure and pencil and you're ready to play.

—description from publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Norgesbanen
description:
The government of Norway has set in motion a plan to create a national railway system.

It cannot do it alone.

Players will invest and run the network, with the government keeping its share of the profits.
As soon as the government has paid its debt on one of the 10 railway lines, the government nationalizes the line and players get a bonus but they will not run it anymore.

Players also try to fill the lines up so they can operate, via cities and towns.
When a line is full, it pays out.

The game ends when the government gets the 7th line.
All other lines are then bought by the government and players tally their cash.
The player with the most cash wins.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Sorcerers' Skirmish
description: Each player takes the role of a sorcerer and is striving to be the last one standing. Using the powers of Water, Fire, Grass and Chaos each turn the players simultaneously casts a spell. The spells resolve based on a rock-paper-scissors mechanic. The actions on each spell are fairly simple. You will either heal yourself, draw more spells, or hurt the target of your spell. The game ends when there is only one sorcerer left standing or a player has run out of spells.

name: Chomageopoly
description:
User summary:

What Chomagepoly is about :

Game made and sold for the benefit of LIP strikers.
This is the antithesis of the game "Monopoly". A kind of goose game that represents the struggle of workers put to unemployment by their company. Players must unite against the opposition forces and fight together against the system: convince the population, put pressure on the government, resist the police, the bosses, and other forces. And find a job.
The player must act for everyone's sake: it's a cooperation game.

How it is played and won:

There is a board (40 squares), "cards" (factory, luck, coordination, balance of power, solidarity), dices, 6 pieces.
We start on the starting square then we advance by rolling the dice and we fall on other boxes (a bit like monopoly).
You can play 3, 4, 5 or 6 players.
Money is replaced by "power relations".

We are not fighting against each other but together to save the companies started closure.

User summary(French):
Un jeu qui est l'inverse du monopoly et qui a été édité par les travailleurs de LIP lors de grèves en 1976.

name: Can of Worms
description:
"Sometimes there's nothing like opening a can of worms to liven up a party. Discover what your friends, family or party goers really think about some of the curliest questions many of us try to avoid, until now. And then learn what Australia really thinks with answers polled nationally by Roy Morgan Research and see if your views are either mainstream or out-of-touch and among the minority? It's non-stop laughter - with some controversy thrown in - that is sure to have everyone talking, well after the game has ended!

How would you answer questions like these?
• Should pole dancing be an Olympic Sport?
• Is it OK to lie to your partner?
• Is opening a car door for a woman sexist?
• Does technology make us lazy?

Contents: 142 Question Cards, 20 Answer Cards, 54 Tokens, Rules."

This game is based on an Australian quiz show. Players secretly answer Yes or No to social questions such as given above, then reveal and may discuss their responses. Points are scored if your answer correlates with Australian population survey responses.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Refuge
description:
Description from the publisher:

It’s no longer safe out there! Zombies have overrun the entire city, eating everyone in their path. You have led a small group of survivors to safety, but you notice that you are dangerously low on supplies. To make matters worse, the military has informed you that a rescue team has been dispatched to your location but they are not expected to arrive for another eight weeks. If you’re going to survive this, you’re going to have to send survivors out to find more supplies, barricade your refuge, and kill as many zombies that you can.

Refuge is a resource-management board game of pure survival. As players wait to be rescued by the military, they must recruit survivors to gather supplies and fight off the zombies and the biker gangs. Players will be forced to trade valuable resources with each other and decrease the zombie population to ensure that everyone lives through this nightmare. However, the zombies and the biker gangs are not your only concern. You will have to find food and water, so that you won’t starve or die of thirst. Also, certain survivors in your refuge demand a little extra in exchange for offering their services, and if you don’t deliver, you and your fellow survivors might not live very long.

name: Skjuub
description:
Description from the publisher:

INTRODUCTION:
Skjuub is a combinatorial game for two players. The name comes from the playing pieces, which are 'skewed cubes'. Skjuubs are 'directional', meaning that their orientation is relevant to gameplay.
Skjuub is in a sense a 'logical successor' to the Series: Tixel of games (Tix, Tixel and Regatta). The form factor is different but the 'gameplay structure' is very similar.

SETUP
Skjuub is played on a 6x6 square grid. Each player has her own pool of 11 pieces, differentiated by color.

A PLAYER'S TURN
On a turn, a player can either place a new skjuub or move one of her own skjuubs already on the board. The orientation of a skjuub (which side the 'overhang' is facing) is decided upon when placing it on the board. A skjuub can be active or inactive and only active skjuubs may be moved.
A skjuub is inactive if at least one of its sides is fully connected to a similarly shaped side of another piece (regardless of color).

NORMAL MOVES; Placement
When placing a new skjuub on the board you are not allowed make one or more opponent skjuubs inactive. A new skjuub may be placed next to one or more already inactive skjuubs in a way in which it becomes inactive itself as well. Such placement does not result in the player getting a bonus move (see section 'BONUS MOVES').

NORMAL MOVES; Sliding and tumbling
A move can be either a slide (in which the orientation of the skjuub remains the same) or a tumble (in which in which the orientation of the skjuub does change - the overhang 'switches' to the opposite side).
In a single move a skjuub may be slid as many squares as wanted (horizontally or vertically along its row or column) but may be tumbled only once (to an adjacent square from where it started the tumble, either in the direction of the overhang or in the opposite direction).
When placing, sliding or tumbling, other skjuubs that are on the board may not be 'disturbed'; their locations and orientations must remain the same.

BONUS MOVES
Chaining moves is important as this temporarily unlocks additional move types (besides placing, sliding and tumbling). If a skjuub that is slid or tumbled is made inactive at its end position - i.e., it's sacrificed - the player gets a bonus move. As a bonus move she can do one of the following:

- one of the normal moves; place, slide or tumble one of her other skjuubs. These slides and tumbles (but not placements) can themselves result in additional bonus moves.
- pick up one of her other skjuubs from the board (not the one skjuub that was just sacrificed!) and place it back in her pool of available skjuubs.
- turn one of her active skjuubs a quarter turn clockwise or anticlockwise. The skjuub that is turned must also still be active after the turn (it may not be sacrificed by the turn).
- pass the bonus move.


When turning a skjuub, other skjuubs that are on the board may not be 'disturbed'. When picking up a skjuub, other skjuubs may temporarily be moved aside to make picking up the skjuub easier but they must be returned to their original locations and orientations afterwards.
One or more other skjuubs can also become inactive by a skjuub being sacrificed. Skjuubs may also be sacrificed adjacent to other skjuubs that are already inactive though (regardless of color).

NO BACKTRACKING
Players are not allowed to undo their previous turn by playing it 'in reverse'. If the previous turn had one or more bonus moves, only the very last bonus move may not be played in reverse.
The main point of the rule is to prevent players from tumbling or sliding one and the same skjuub back and forth in consecutive turns. Therefor it is allowed to pick up a skjuub that was placed in the previous turn. Players are also allowed to alternate between sliding and tumbling the same skjuub repeatedly.
There is one exception to the rule: Backtracking is allowed if it captures an opponent piece (and the piece that does the backtracking becomes inactive itself too).

ENDING THE GAME
A player loses the game if, at the beginning of her turn, she does not have at least one active skjuub on the board that is both able and allowed to slide and/or tumble.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Tile Placement

name: Blinded by Science Trivia Game
description: Players answer science-based trivia questions for points. Once a predetermined number of cards have been read, highest score wins.

name: Time Dice
description:
In Time Dice, you represent an independent group bent on setting history right! You seed history with events and then correct those events for the betterment of humanity. But remember: time marches on and the future can be fickle! You must use your resources to change the past and protect the future while not causing too many paradoxes!

The goal of the game is to manipulate the past and present to secure objectives. Each game has 11 objectives you can satisfy. The player with the most satisfied objectives and fewest paradoxes creates the most stable timeline and is declared the winner.

The game is played over six rounds, each consisting of rolling five dice - keep four to use as your Alteration Values to change history and one to seed as your next event in the timeline. Be careful! The ripples caused by certain Alteration Values can affect more than just the present! Can you master the past to perfect the future and secure all of your objectives?

name: HurriCount
description:
Description from the publisher:

Easy as one-two-three. Whoever counts the hedgehogs and birds the fastest yells “Got it” and collects the harvest! The originally designed game set in compact packaging with bright an unusual animal drawings is a great solution for this fun game and complementary for acquiring the basics of mathematics. Play and get smarter. This game is played in background mode, so you won’t have to convince your child to sit down at the table. Not only will children learn how to count, but they will instantly learn to define the number of objects on a card as well, which definitely separates this method of learning from cramming in a positive light. Adding within ten can easily become second nature to your child. HurriCount is a great supplement for developing your child’s attentiveness, logic, thinking speed, and reaction time. HurriCount has an application called HurriCount Mathitude where you will get to solve problems that are even more challenging. The cards from this game can be gradually added into HurriCount, making it more difficult, and you can also use it as a standalone playing set. When buying the two games at the same time, you will be able to receive a cut little bag that you can carry the games in.

name: Meine Farben und Formen
description:
Round and square - red, yellow, blue. Where are the square, triangle and circle hidden?
The three friends, monkey, rabbit and cat invite you to a journey through the world of colors and shapes. With colorful toys, the child first learns the basic colors and gradually acquires the most important forms. The children sort the colors apart. In the next step, the small players assign shapes. They play on one of many differen game boards, which the child himself has chosen. Where do the circle, triangle and quadrangle belong? Now the monkey, rabbit and cat have their appearance: in the combination of color and shape knowledge, the children organize the forms on different picture boards appropriately. Depending on the development step, additional shapes or the dice will come into play. Through numerous game variations the children in Meine Farben und Formen strengthen basic basic knowledge.

name: Sute Sute Marketing
description:
Sute Sute Marketing is a game about collecting items like erasers, milk caps or calendars and becoming the top collector of that items.

In your turn you draw 2 cards and have to discard 1 card. Discarded cards are grouped together with other cards of the same number. When the stack runs out the game ends.
The cards you keep in your hand will determine if you are the top collector. If you have for example the most milk cap cards at the end of the game you are the top collector and get the discarded milk cap. The 2nd collector, the one who collected second most milk caps will get the hand cards of the top collector as points.
Whoever has the most points (cards) is the winner of the game
publishers: Chicken Dice Games (チキンダイスゲームズ), Loserdogs

name: Trick Taking City
description:
User summary:
トリック・テイキング・シティ Trick Taking City is a trick taking game with a theme of city building.

In this game, cards represent some facility of a city, and players play a trick taking game using these cards. There are four suits: Agricultural, Commercial, Residential, and Industrial. Additionally, there are several special facilities that trump others and may be played anytime.

The winner of a trick takes a card from the cards on the table, and places it in front of themself, forming a part of that player's city. Other players retrieve a card from the table for future use.

At the end of the game, players score points according to facility locations in their city, and the highest scorer wins the game.

When should you win a trick and when should you lose? Estimating the situation is the key to winning the game.

『Trick Taking City』はシティービルドとトリックテイキングを合体させたゲームとなります。

各プレーヤーは建物カードを使ってトリックテイキングを行います。
トリックの勝者は、場のカードから1枚を選んで自身の街スペースに建築します。
勝者以外は次のハンドの手札になります。
最終的に完成させる4枚×4枚の広さの街で、できるだけ得点が高くなるようにしよう。というゲームです。

どこで勝ちにいってどこで負けにいくか。押し引きが重要なゲームとなっています。

name: Stellar Wars
description:
User summary:

A set of rules for fighting tactical spaceship battles using 1/3000 scale miniatures. The game consists of a 46-page digest-sized rulebook and an insert with game charts and tables.

The spaceship design rules offer a unique approach. The number and type of components that a player can install on a spaceship depends on the physical dimensions of the miniature figure being used to portray the ship. The game was designed to be directly compatible with lines of spaceship miniatures produced by several manufacturers, and the rules include listings specifying the volume of individual miniature spaceships from various manufacturers.

name: The Caster Chronicles
description:
A mysterious academy hides a dark secret. Girls form magical contracts and participate in magical battles using enchanted cards in this exciting new card game from the creators of Force of Will. Assemble your Casters and call Servants in this exciting and engaging new card game system. The Caster Chronicles is sure to push your strategy, will, and magic to the absolute limit!

The Caster Chronicles is a Japanese trading card game created by the Force of Will game company.

Play caster cards to generate aether, which you then use to play servants, conjures, and barriers to attack your enemy.

In this turn based game, players trade off amassing the game’s resource, called aether. They then use that aether to summon servants, use conjures and barriers for support. By using your forces you can attack your opponent. Destroy all seven of your opponent’s orbs and then attack your opponent one final time to win the game!

From the publisher

name: Party People: Holiday Edition
description: All Party People name tags can be combined to make larger sets. Each set includes a game for 2 or more players. All name tags and beads are plastic. Holiday Edition is a game of improv where players try to win rounds against other players by talking in character about the scenario a judge describes. The first player to win 3 rounds wins the game.

name: Star Gazer
description:
You have the power to move the stars!

Stargazers add, remove and swap stars to create stellar patterns. The Stargazer who earns the most points before a stack of Gazer Cards runs out, is the winner! Gazer Cards show the Star Token pattern you must complete on the Galaxy Board to earn the point value on the card. On your turn, you may play and/or discard up to 5 Star Cards to move the Star Tokens and complete the pattern on your Gazer Card.

—description from the rulebook

name: Kalandra fel!  Magyarországon
description:
In this Hungarian board you have to travel in Hungary, answer questions about the country, the castles, lakes, rivers, bridges, and show it on the map of Hungary.
Its an ideal game for student and the family.

—user summary

name: Garçon!: En délire!!!
description:
Garçon! En délire!!! is a reimplementation of Garçon. It is a card game in which the players hold the role of waiters in a Café Bar. Their objective is to memorize orders to gain tips, but in order to carry them it will be necessary to judiciously use the Event Cards, to thwart the plans of the other players.

The main difference with the original game is the goofiness of the ingredient names as “Jus de limace” (slug juice), “Sodas Inconnus” (a game play around “Soldats inconnu”, ie. “Unknown soldier”) or “2 MiMoore” (read in french as Demi Moore). This renders the orders far more difficult to memorize.

The game consists of 55 cards and is suited for 3–10 players Ages 7 and up (but is this a pun about the soda drink?).
categories: Humor, Memory, Party Game, Word Game

name: Spirit Realms: Tengoku-SR
description:
Spirit Realms: Tengoku-SR is a 2-4 player army fort builder card game that revolves around a retelling of the gods as animal warrior spirits called Spirit Masters. Each warrior is Ruler of 1 of the 9 realms in the world of Tengoku, SR Prime being the first realm. Each realm is represented by a Spirit Master who comes with his own deck of power, each deck with it's own strengths and weakness. Some decks are magic based, with tech elements some are Mental based with Earth elements while some decks are defensive and others are passive. You can choose which characters and deck(s) represent your goals and personal strategy, and play them as stand alones or combine them with other decks to create your own unique decks.

Players must protect their throne by defending their forts from being destroyed while attempting to capture their opponent's Throne. Players get to build forts and barriers while using minions to build armies, while learning basic gameplay players are able to invent unique strategies.

name: Leap Frog
description: Leap Frog is a game created in New Zealand where opponents pieces are captured by leaping over them. To start each player in turn places one of their four counters in any slot of the nine slots around the circle on the board. Each player in turn then performs a slide move, double jump or jump move, though if the next player can not move, the player who just moved takes another turn. The first player to capture all four of his opponents pieces wins the game.

name: Image Factory
description:
A robot-themed, cooperative "drawing quiz game".

All players but one draw two "theme cards" and draw a character representing the combination of the words written (i.e. "Dog" and "President") in 30 seconds.

After drawing a character, all "theme cards" are gathered and shuffled. A number of extra cards may be added, depending on player count.

The one player who did not draw that round must select the correct combination that applies to each drawing from among the mixed cards.

name: Maestro Nefario
description: Card game with music theme and combines a 3x3 grid, invoking that of tic-tac-toe. 2 players compete to create the patterns required for performing music pieces.

name: Monopoly: Belkin
description:
Belkin offers a diverse product mix that provides people with seamless electronics integration in their homes, cars, and on the go. Founded in California in 1983, Belkin is a privately held company and the recognized leader in connectivity solutions, in addition to accessories for MP3 devices, computers, and more. We provide extensive solutions for networking, home theater with our PureAV" line of cables, power, and digital wireless accessories and many more categories. You can view and purchase them at www.belkin.com, as well as through network of major distributors, resellers, and superstores.

Belkin's phenomenal growth has led to our expanding global presence, which is why we thought Belkin was a great fit for a Monopoly game. We hope your family and friends will enjoy buying, selling and trading Belkin locations worldwide while pursuing the dream of owning it all. What a better way to visit all of our offices than through the exciting game of Monopoly!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: University of Washington
description:
Go Huskies TM!

Monopoly, the legendary game of property and money, and the University of Washington, the celebrated university of academics and research, team up to create a classic board game for Husky M fans everywhere. Take a spin around the bdard to find the best loved buildings and scenes of one oRAntErRa's great universities. And be prepared to pay big bucks if you and Denny Hall or en Library the first building on campus and the campus' main library doesn't come cheap!

Grab your friends and family, put on your Husky M sweatshirt and enter the halls of UW for the game of your life. The Hub, Red Square, McMahon Hall, Burke Museum or 22 other UW properties can all be yours. Whether a student, alumnus or fan, can you resist the chance to buy Washington's finest?

GAME INCLUDES Game Board. Property Cards. Play Money and Banker's Tray. 2 Dice. 10 Game Tokens. Chance Cards. Community Chest. Cards. Package of Dormitories. Package of Houses.

Photography courtesy of University of Washington Athletics Media Relations and University Photography. Center Board Photo by Loyd C. Heath.
—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Bushido: Yuui Ito
description:
Another daughter of Orochi, a ferocious warrior gifted with great prowess in battle and the honour of Orochi’s snake form body. She slithers across the battlefield seeking out the cowards in the shadows and dispatching them in Orochi’s name. Although not of the Ito bloodline Yuui has risen amongst the ranks of the followers of Orochi, a rise that has not gone unnoticed by many Ito, who by birth should outrank her.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Manu
description:
This giant Buto is the personal bodyguard of Harukichi and was selected for obvious reasons. His prowess in the Jumo arenas quickly attracted attention, it was clear to most he was destined for a top position within the Syndicate, and he has not disappointed. Constantly vigilant to any threat, and unshakeable in his devotion to the defence of his Oyabun, Manu has continuously put himself in harm’s way, catching most would be assassins off guard with his prowess in melee, deftly blocking blows until his master is safe, then and only then the time comes to crush bones with fists the size of mallets.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Mein cooles Dino-Spiel
description: Each player chooses a dinosaur skeleton outline and places it in front of him/her on the table. The dinosaur bones are placed into a fabric bag. Now the players have to find the matching bones for their dinosaur without looking. They roll the die and according to the number thrown they may take 1, 2 or 3 dino bones from the fabric bag or put the bones together which they have already found. The game ends as soon as one of the players has completely assembled his/her dino.

name: Blots
description:
Blots is a new monster-themed party game in which players try to explain as many words as they can in under one minute. There are six different methods of explanation--and you will use all of them during the game! The game also features six levels of difficulty and a major twist: players do not split into teams, but each time players guess a word, that pair of players advance their marker on the score track. At the end of the game, the winner will be that pair of players who best understand each other in the process.

—description from the publisher (paraphrased)

name: Battles of 1866: Blood & Iron
description:
As war loomed over Germany in the early summer of 1866, Bavaria aligned itself with Austria against Prussia and armed for war. The Bavarian chief of staff, Ludwig Freiherr von der Tann, met with the Austrian leadership and suggested that the Bavarian army march into Bohemia. There they would form the left wing of the Austrian North Army, and along with the Saxons would hold off the Prussian First Army at Jicin while the Austrians dealt with the Prussian Second Army.

Von der Tann’s bold plan might well have given the Allies victory, but the Austrian commander, Ludwig von Benedek, turned him down and Bavaria pursued a separate strategy. By the time Benedek changed his mind and called for the Bavarians to advance, it was already too late.

Battles of 1866: Blood & Iron is an expansion book for Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles. It adds the Royal Bavarian Army to the game, based on the Von der Tann plan. There are six scenarios included plus background on the Jicin campaign and the Bavarian proposal to participate. While this battle never took place, the scenarios are based on actual operational plans.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Area-Impulse, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Learn + Fun: Formen + Farben
description:
Children can go on a journey of discovery with these couloured pieces and learn about shapes and colours while they play. They discover basic geometric shapes and learn how to distinguish colours. The exact fitting in of game pieces promotes fine motor skills. Children compare the colours and shapes and have to assign them correctly. This promotes observation and concentration.

—description from the rulebook

name: Bushido: Jirobo
description:
Jirobo is a great haiatake warrior, imbued with a natural talent in combat, he is able to judge his opponent’s subtle movements. The weight changed in their stance, the snatched glance that gives away their intent. This brave tengu is then able to adjust, either by counter attacking or building an iron clad defence of steel.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: すぺーす・ぺっとしょっぷ (Space Petshop)
description:
User summary
すぺーす・ぺっとしょっぷ (Space Petshop) is a Japanese card game. Players try to get the highest points by making a “set” from two cards that have been placed face up in the playing field.

The players want to create a high scoring set, but the difficult point is that there are not so many high point cards.

Try to make as many high scoring sets as possible.

Publisher's summary
場にめくられたカードを取得して２枚１組の「セット」を作ることで高得点を目指します。
高い点数の「セット」を作ることができればより高得点になりますが、
点数が高いカードは枚数が少なくセットにするのが難しいです。
できるだけ高得点になるようにセットを作っていきましょう。

name: Fortune & Folly
description:
In Fortune & Folly, each player manages their own trading house in a fantasy world set roughly in the Elizabethan era. Grow your trading company by commissioning new ships and direct your fleets to win monopolies on key trade routes and harbors in a race to be recognized as the Queen’s Royal Trading Company!
 
SUMMARY:
Fortune & Folly is a worker management game with a rich nautical theme and very approachable rules. Event cards are drawn each turn and serve the dual purpose of normalizing game length and driving strategies that become more complex as players get more comfortable with the ecosystem at work in the game’s mechanics. But getting into the adventure is easy. You start with three ships and move them between harbors and routes to score points based on the price of the goods moved over that route. Winning harbors allows you to place more ships and grow your fleet. When the last event card is resolved, the player with the highest score wins!

GAMEPLAY OVERVIEW:
Players start with a fleet of three ships on the board and can grow their fleet to ten by commanding monopolies on the harbor islands. Use trade ships to claim trade routes and gain Fortune points and direct pirates to harry your enemy company's efforts. Players will plan and then take each step of their turn with the help of their turn order card which includes a step to choose a world event card. Three of these events are shown next to the deck, so you'll have three shown options during this phase, or you can choose the top card of the deck at random. Once there are too few event cards to replenish the four options, the current player takes their turn and game is scored. Whoever has the most Fortune wins!

Each turn you will: 
1) Draw and resolve a card
2) Move a ship to a route or harbor island sharing a way point 
3/4) Optionally, you may get to make additional moves, or move pirate ships around
5) Score points for routes you monopolize 
6) Place new ships for each harbor island you monopolize

ATTRIBUTES:
There are four dice, but they are used as counters for commodity prices. 
There are always the same number of turns because of the number of World Event cards and there's a mechanic called the Royal Court card that is used to speed up games that start to run a little longer due to players' deliberating more over their turns.  
The World Event cards present the only real randomness in the game, but you'll always have four options (including the option to pick a card at random). 
A strategy guide is included in the rule book, so you can really hit the ground running.

Designer Notes:
This game is meant to be super easy to get learn, even for those just getting into the hobby, but to introduce layers as you become familiar with the mechanics.
You'll be carefully planning your move and thinking like a shrewd trade company manager in no time!
This game was developed over the course of almost two decades and we're so proud of how it turned out. Many thanks to Erwin Arozza for his contribution of stunning artwork that we think really brings the rich nautical, sometimes piratey, theme to life.
